intro: Potentilla haematochroa, commonly known as the blood-red cinquefoil, is a perennial shrub native to the mountainous regions of central and eastern Europe. It belongs to the Rosaceae family and is characterized by its narrow, dark green leaves and showy, bright red flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and is often found in rocky or gravelly soils. Its flowers are actinomorphic, with five petals, and it produces small, red berries that are an important food source for birds and small mammals. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
